# SketchJS
## Fast class sketching — code structure and class diagrams from simple text


A browser-based tool to parse a custom domain-specific language (DSL) for defining classes, properties, and functions with simple indentation syntax, and generate JavaScript class code and Mermaid diagrams from it to downlad as [markdown](exampleDownloadFile.md).

It is more the idea of... for now very basic and simple
___
## What is this?

This project lets you:

- Write simple indented text to define classes, their properties (including nested inline objects), parameters, methods, and standalone functions.
- Parse that DSL in-browser to produce fully-formed JavaScript ES6 class definitions.
- Generate Mermaid class diagrams visualizing the relationships and structures you defined.
- View a structured summary of parsed classes and their properties.
- Export your DSL input, generated JS code, and Mermaid diagram as a Markdown file.

It’s handy if you want a quick way to prototype class definitions visually and programmatically without writing raw JS upfront.
___
## How to use

1. Open the HTML file in a modern browser.
2. Enter your class/function DSL into the left textarea.
3. Click Generate to see:
   - JavaScript ES6 class code in the output panel.
   - A class structure summary with collapsible sections.
   - A Mermaid class diagram visualizing class relationships.
4. Optionally, export everything as a Markdown file with diagrams embedded.




---

## Features

- Parses an indented DSL syntax with classes, properties, methods, and functions
- Supports typed properties, default values, nested inline objects
- Generates JS classes with constructors and stub methods
- Generates standalone JS functions
- Renders collapsible structure diagrams and Mermaid class diagrams
- Supports exporting DSL input, JS code, and Mermaid diagrams as Markdown

---

## DSL Syntax Overview

- Top-level lines ending with `:` define classes or functions section
- Classes have subsections `props:`, `parameters:`, `methods:`
- Indentation is tab-based
- Properties *can* be:
  - Typed (e.g. `name: string = "default"`)
  - Simple with default (e.g. `age = 0`)
  - Nested inline objects (e.g. `address: { street: string, city: string = "Unknown" }`)

---

## Example DSL

```dsl
Person:
	props:
		name: string = "Unknown"
		age: number = 0
		address: {
			street: string
			city: string = "Unknown"
		}
	methods:
		greet()

functions:
	sayHello(name)
```

---

## Generated JavaScript Output

```js
class Person {
  constructor(name, age, args = {}) {
    this.name = name !== undefined ? name : "Unknown";
    this.age = age !== undefined ? age : 0;
    this.address = args.address ?? { street: null, city: "Unknown" };
  }

  greet() {
    log("Running 'greet'");
    // TODO: Implement greet
  }
}

function sayHello(name) {
  log("Running 'sayHello'");
  // TODO: Implement sayHello
}
```

---

![Mermaid Diagram](data:image/svg+xml;base64,)

(Well, this is pretty boaring)

___

## How to Use

1. Write your DSL in the input area (or edit the example above)
2. The parser will generate JavaScript classes/functions automatically
3. View generated code and diagrams for easy understanding
4. Export or copy as needed



## Why publish it?

- It’s a practical proof-of-concept for quick DSL-driven class scaffolding and visualization.
- Useful for planning and documenting class designs.
- Could grow into a neat little web app with further refactoring and UI polish.

## Current status

- The codebase is fairly monolithic and reklly messy — it’s a personal prototype and needs a lot of love to structure and refactor nicely..
- Parsing and generation logic is all in one place for easy iteration.
- Contributions VERY welcome for ideas, refactoring, adding features, or improving UX.

## Technologies used

- Vanilla JavaScript, no frameworks
- Mermaid.js for diagrams
- CSS for basic styling

## How to run locally

Just open `index.html` (or your main HTML file) in any modern browser. No build step required.

## Possible improvements

- Add more options
- Modularize parsing, generation, and rendering code
- Add real-time parsing with error highlighting
- UI/UX polish with better styling and interactions
- Export to other formats (JSON, UML, etc.)
- Integrate with backend for saving/loading projects
